div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: MOROCCO ANU ABYSSINIA
div.p: One of the many writers on Africa said some years ago, that throughout the continent, from North to South, there exists some subtle climatic influence which, acting on human nerves, tends to make the people very quarrel - soma This is said to apply not Only to natives, but more particularly to foreigners. It is, we thick, admitted that the experience of recent years has quite justified this opinion, by along series of events still so freshly before us that it is not necessary to recapitulate them. The disputed question of most immediate importance is that of Morocco. This question has loomed largely before os for many month', but it is. probably,, now only a matter of days before some of the results of the Conference of Algesiras will be known to the world. Already there rooms to be a general opinion that although this question has given rise to a good deal of anxiety, an amicable settlement will probably be arrived at We sincerely hope that this will be so, sad we should have been still more pleased if we could have looked forward to the future with a sigh of relief at . the idea that African questions bad subsided fora while But,however s satisfactory may be the news we all anxiously await from Algesiras. we regret to say that it may not be long before another African question became* acute, and this time if will interest Egypt more nearly than does the question of Morocco. We refer to Abyssinia. For the last twelve years a question has been brewing there which "promises to result in a very considerable crop of internatioral difficulties It all began with what would appear at first sight to be almost simple- matter, which, in view of the serious complications likely to arise from it, merits some in 1893, some friends of the Emperor Menelik expressed the wish to make a railway for him from the Red Sea to hit capital. Hitherto most of the Abyssinian exports were taken in a clumsy sort of way by caravan to the port of Zaila in British Somaliland, for our readers will remember that one of the difficulties of Abyssinian development is that it has no sea. coast of its own, and it results from many rather cunningly devised international arrangements that Menelik has to pass through foreign territory, either French, British, or Italian, before he can get to any ports It might appear to some people that after the successful war which England waged against Abyssinia some, forty years ago, the British Government might have secured this exclusive advantage, for the expedition had been a 'costly one ; bat so far as we can remember the principal result has been that an English nobleman takes his title from the then capital of Abyssinia. We cannot remember exactly what constituted the French title to their part of Somaliland, but at all events they have it, and it includes the port of Djibouti. In 1893 Menelik's friends were French or acting in French interests, and it naturally occurred to them that it would be a good thing to make a railway from Djibouti, and thus take away the trade, with its large prospect of future development, from Zaila. The line would then pass for a distance of about 50 miles through French territory. Although this line was expressly intended to be a purely commercial undertaking, and Menelik was naturally anxious to secure the advantages of development which it would open out, he was still cautious enough stipulate that he would wait and see how he got on with his new friends and their railway as far as Harrar, or not quite half way from the sea to his capital, before he gave them any permission to take their line on to Adis Abeba. Subsequent events have shown that be was exceedingly well advised. It would take us much beyond the limits of this article to trace the interesting development of this railway question ; we intend to return to it again in a few days in greater detoil. For the moment we will only summarise in a few words the facts that, as is not unusual in similar undertakings, the railway company got into financial difficulties, the line cost more than was expected it always does,— the company being French, had naturally to appeal to the French Government to get it out of its difficulties, .long negotiations follow- el, ending in the whole thing being entirely converted from a commercial into a political undertaking, and this, "mirabile dicta,".without it being considered necessary to consult t Menelik about it in any way. Later on the" somewhat meagre funds allotted by the French Government were exhausted, and a New African Company and a New Egyptian Company had to be called to the rescue. Still later Menelik became so disgusted with the conduct of his. friends, that in May, 1905, he convened the representatives of the four European Powers principally interested, and told them very plainly what he thought about the action of the railway company, and added that if be did not very shortly receive some much more reasonable proposals he would make the line himself from Harrar on to hie capital at Adis Abeba' a distance of about 300 miles. Although the "entente eordiale" 'between England and France did not refer to Abyssiuis we still think that it- would have been of much assistance in bringing matters to an understanding if the question had been I ft to the only Governments much interested in it until quite recently ; we mean those of France, England, and Italy, but unfortunately Germany has now appeared on the scene, and after the not very successful mission of Dr Rosen, is sending a Minister to the Court of the Emperor Menelik, probably with the laudable wish of taking advantage of the rivalries of the other nations. In spite of the rather cool reception he got from. Menelik, Dr. Rosen is said to be determined to acquire commercial equality in Abyssinia, and to assist in the establishment of trade communi-cations between that country and the coast. He apparently does not consider the fact that these communications must necessarily be made through either French, British, or Italian territory to be of much importance. We must say that we feel much sympathy with the Ethiopeans monarch in his struggles with civilisation, and if he wishes to make his railway line himself, vhy should he not be allowed to do so. if he cau And perhaps now that fie has a Bank, he may be able- to raise the necessary funds.

British Chamber of Commerce.

The annual general time ting of members of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt will be held on Wednesday, 7 th February, at 4 p.m , in Messrs Carver Bros. & Company's offices, Old Bourse Street, Alexandria, to receive the committee's report and accounts for the year 1905, and to elect four members to the committee for 1906.
Execution.

Abdel Malek Hussein Mahmoud, of Dsir- monos, who murdered Shahda Ghibrial, a native soman of that Village on the 27 th August last,- was executed yesterday morning in the prison of the Native Court of Appeal, Cairo. The condemned man's relatives were allowed to see him in the prison before execution, and to bury his body afterwards.
Men Frozen In Cairo.

Three workmen employed in the ice factory belonging to the Crown Brewery in Cairo were discovered by a policeman lying motion less in the iceworks, having become benumbed from the effects of cold. * The manager was promptly informed and restoratives were im mediately applied. One of the men recovered, but the other two were taken to hospital in a precarious condition.
Soldiers' Club. ;

It is proposed to ho'd a birfiard tournament at the Soldiers' Club, Cairo, early in February, on the football cup system (150 points), by teams of four from any one unit, or honorary members. An unlimited number of teams may enter from any unit, let prize, value £5 5s. Od.; 2nd prize, value £3,88. Od. A special prise of a championship billiard* match one will be given to the maker of the highest break in the tournament.
Concert.

A most successful concert was given in the drawing room of the New Khedivial Hotel on 8atnrday afternoon the pupils of the violin master, Professor Artelli. The whole of the programme was carried out by Professor Artel li's pupils and the young dilettanti did great credit both to themselves and to their teacher, Where there was fo much excellence it is diffi­cult to particularise, but the violin duet given by the Misses Netty and Regina Soheratter was especially appreciated and much applaud, ed. Little Master Snares and Mile. Palagi also received much applause.
Music at the Hotels.

The Savoy Restaurant is very much "en vogue" this season and a great number of dinner parties are given every evening. The management of the George Nungovioh Hotels Co. having engaged three different, orchestras the Ladies' Band, the Tzigane Orchestra, and the Bracale band, this has been found a great attraction to the habitues of the Savoy. Last evening's concert was by Mr. Bracale's grand orchestra and the afternoon concert by the Ladies' Band. Tuesday's concerts, afternoon and evening are by the Sextette, and Wedres- day's concerts by the Ladies' Band.
The Sphinx."

We have much pleasure in calling the attention of our readers to the excellent number of the ' Sphinx" which appeared last Saturday. As usual, it contains reading of much interest to both residents and visitors. We would especially mention the unique illustrations of the ancient Mosaic made by the Romans some two. thousand years ago at Palestrina, giving a vivid idea of the state of affairs on the Nile in those days. We would recommend all who are interested in subjects Egyptological and the like to purchase a copy without delay, ss ,was are 'informed that there are only a few copies left.

div.head: OMDEHS AND SHEIKHS PUNISHED
div.p: The Minieh Moadirieh his dismissed the sheikh of the ezbeh "Fabrikat Magbagha" and sentenced him to one month's imprisonment for falsely asserting that Fome woman of his village had beaten his wife, his object being to avenge himself against the woman, owing to the fact that she had gained a case against him. The Moudirieh also imposed a penalty of L.B.5 on the omdeh of Ban El-Alam, Magbagha Marksz, for negleoting'to inform the Madras authorities of the outbreak of small pox before it spread in his village ; and dismissed 'he sheikh of Belham Magbagha Market, at the same time inflicting a fine of LB. 5, for his having asked the omdeh to look over a charge
of theft.

div.head: ZAGAZIG MIXED MUNICIPALITY
div.p: A Zagazig correspondent writes We are at last blessed with a Mixed Municipality, a dream we all longed to see realised. For years former moudirs had tackled this complicated question without success, owing to the many difficulties it presented. OurMoudrr, Mohamed Bey Moheb, is therefore to be congratulated on his triumph, due exclusively to his dogged tenacity, perseveranoe, and tact His expe­rience in municipal matters has also stood him in good stead, for was it not he that created the Fayoum Municipality?

The elections took place on the 17th inst, commencing at 10 a.m sharp, and closing at 2 p.m.The chosen members are the following:— Europeans : MM. Sefth Berla, Janm Trian dafilou, Em. Calambokides, and Walter Berla. Natives : Ismail Pacha Abaza, Amn Pacha Shamsy, Sid Ahmed Bay Dib, and Mahmoud Bey Gamal.

Never had Zsgarg seen such a scene. Na­tives and Europeans intermingled in a friendly way, all keen and happy to vote. Mr. Varov ha placed his hotel "Hotel d'Egypte" at the dispo sal of the Moudir for the purpose. A band at night played a welcome tune to each elected member.

Much is now expected of the Municipality, and our City Fathers have an arduous task facing them. Water, light, and paving the streets have to be provided for, besides many other minor necessities. Their success is, however, assured with a man like Moheb Bey at the helm.

div.head: A NEW COMPANY
div.p: REGULAR SERVICE NOW BEGUN.

On Sunday afternoon the Nile Motor Boat Company gave its inaugural trip.This company has been started by the hotel porters of the Savoy, Ghezireh Palace, Shspheard's, and the Grand Continental Hotels, and its objects is to furnish residents and tourists with luxurious and swift steamers for trips on the Ni'e The diet at present consists of three boats, the Clec^> fra the Aida, and the Alms.

The regular service began yesterday (Mon day). I here will be two trips a day to the Bar­rage and buck and one trip daily to B drachein for Sakkara. The boats are all of American build, having been designed and constructed by Trascott, of St. Joseph, Michigan. Each has an engine of twelve horse power and carries sixteen passengers. They maintain a speed of ten kilometres per hour against the current and seventeen kilometres down stream.

It is intended to gradually increase the present fleet, for the operations of the com­pany are bound to extend. Not only the tourists but also the residents Are to be catered for. and during the summer there will be plenty of work for the boats in taking residents for picnics and pleasure trips. The river is a delightful resort during the hot weather and the fleet of the Nile Motor Boat Company should be as well patronised in the summer as in the winter months.

The boats are very convenient in regard to size and especially suitable for private parties. They are each 1 m. 80 cm. in breadth and 10 metres in length. The space allotted to the passengers is four metres in extent The engines burn benzine and there is no smoke Even. whsn going at full speed they keep very steadyand there is hardly any vibration. There is a Euro pean chauffeur and an Arab ries for each boat

The inauguration of the Nile Motor Boat Company on Sunday afternoon was a great success and the trip from Cairo to the Barrage and back was made under the most pleasant circumstances. On arriving at the Barrage, the tables with which each boat is fitted were brought ashore, and amidst the beautiful sur­roundings of the Barrage gardens these were laid out with a plenteous stock of champagne and sand wiches. The success of the company was drunk with much enthusiasm and a most enjoyable afternoon was spent.

Xenophen Cambicci and the manager and general agent of - the company is Mr. E. P. Blattner. We wish the Nile Motor Boat Company e/ery succes and we oirdially congratulate its promoters on their enterprise in having organised such a useful undertaking, which should be well patronised by visitors and residents.

div.head: ANOTHER CONTRACT
div.p: OBTAINED BY ENGLISH FIRM.

Messrs. Ransomes and Rapier, Ltd., have just obtained contract for the sluices, look gates end sluices, and the swing bridge for the new Emeh Barrage, the masonry contract for which Messrs. J. Aird and Co. are to have.

The contract was signed on Saturday, and all details of the contract are now completed direct with the Government.. It is hoped that the four years provided in the contract for completion may be anticipated.

There are 120 sluice openings (nine more than at Assiout) and the sluices are to be of an improved design so as to be much more basily worked. The winches are also of a new design and arranged so that one can do the -work of four of the type hitherto used in Egypt
The three years guarantee of the Assouan
Sir William Garatin and Mr. Webb are said to be exceedingly pleased with the firm's work there. as it has not required any repairs during the three years,nor given any trouble whatever.

The Bsneh Barrage is for the purpose of regulating the level of water only at high Nile in years when it would otherwise be too low to give the required flooding over the land, both above and also below the site, by means of the oanals which take off from the river above the barrage site.
Mr. Wilfrid Stokes,.who signed the contract on Saturday, is managing director of the company,, and took a leading part in the Assouan sluice work both in England and from time to time in Egypt.

div.head: NEW BRITISH CLUB
div.p: We are pleased to learn that the new British Club at Alexandria will open on the 1st February The site of the club premises is very good, being in the Zouro Building in Ramleh Boulevard. Although only 185 mem­bers have so far joined, we understand other names will follow as soon as the club ie open, and seeing the committee have only had a month to get the club in working order we think great credit is due to the committee for opening it in so abort a time. It is probable that some would be donors and sub­scribers have been inadvertently overlooked io the first circular sent out. This always happens, and we are. asked to make it known that anyone wi-hing to join the club should communicate with the bon. secretary, Mr A. R Purvis, or any members of the committee. We understand that the billiard tables will he here before the end of this month and will he erected as quickly as possible.

div.head: A PIANOFORTE RECITAL
div.p: Mme. Bonuci Carlesimos scond concert was a triumph, and the ball room of the Grand Continental Hotel was crowded. Her per­formance was splendid throughout. We pre ferred perhaps S humann's Carnival Uf any­thing else, hot the Polonaise in B fiat (Chopin) was marvellous'/ good, and here Mme. Bonucci Carlesimo dared to attempt a piece which few male performer can play with real success—and succeeded. M. Saint-Saeoa listen ed and admired and was the first to oongra tulate the performer after her fine rendering of Beethoven's Appassionata.

Mme. Bonocci-Carlesimo leaves, alas 1 for Paris and this season we shall hear her no more. She will succeed in Paris, of that we feel sure, and we hope to hear her in Cairo next winter. Pianists of her abilities are rare in the world.

div.head: DESCRIPTION OF PROPERTY
TO BE PARCELLED OUT IN LOTS.
div.p: We stated in our issue of last Saturday that a very important purchase of agricultural land had been made by the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co. We now learn that the property in question is situated at Baatara, near Damanboor, and withirt 20 minutes carnage drive of that town. It consists of 1,500 feddaqs of the best land and was bought from Messrs. Emile and Jacques Tabet at the prioe of LE. 100,000, payable on the transfer of the title deeds. There are 5 or 6 wall populated villages on the estate. It is one of the best laid out properties in that part of the country and has been under the im mediate softer vision of one of the former owners during the 8 or 4 years the land has been in their possession. Two large cajals traverse the property so that there is an ample supply of water, and what is of import ance is the fact that so plentiful ie the supply no pumping machinery is required to irrigate the land. Although it is already in a high state of cultivation the estate is oapable of still farther development with a judicious oat lay of a little more money.

We understand the oompany intends in all probability to parcel the property into plots of different dimensions so as to meet the require­ments and theaus of the small landowners and fellaheen, to whom it would be sold, in that case, on the most favorable terms, the pay­ments being spread over a number of years.
There ie a large brick factory adjoining one of the villages where bricks are made for supplying the neighbourhood and the adjacent towns, and this factory is considered a'vainable asset.

div.head: INTERESTING JUDGEMENTS
div.p: The January Bulletin of the Native Tribu nals contain! some interesting judgments from which we releot the following summaries, which are of some importance :
In state representative v moh. Abdel Fat- tak, tried before the Court of Cassation, the following judgement was given

A person is guilty of forgery who, without the knowledge or the consent of the owner of a seal, affixes its impress upon a document purporting to be a conveyance of land belong­ing to such owner and it is immaterial whether the impress be affixed by means of a genuine or a spurious, seal. Consequently, where such document bears the impress of a genuine seal thus fraudulently affixed, a person who, know- ing it to be forged set, it up against the owner, is guilty of uttering a forgery.
In Mustapha Eff. Ahead v Ahmed Mohamed Yovutf the jadgment is summarised as follows .

I. The right of pre emption does not arise from contract. Its nature is similar to that of the right of expropriation Hence before the Decree 23 Maroh 1901 came into operation, the native do arts had jurisdiction to try a presmption suit when the pre emptor and the fact that the vendor was an alien and that the sale had been effected under the Mixed Bode

IL The obligation arising under the preemption decree to join the vendor as party to the suit does not merely concern the pro- cedars but affects the existence of 'the right to pre-empt. It has not consequently any retrospective effect-!

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: On Friday, 19th inst a match was played between "H" Co. K R.R. and the Railway Insti­tute at Gezireh BadraneThe home team lost the toes.Ere the game was fifteen minutes old the visitors managed to score 3 goals. Then all of a sudden the home team woke up out of their slumber as it seemed and after deeper ate attacks scored a goal. When the. teams changed over the score stood 3—1 in "H" Co's favour. On the resumption of play the railway men played for all. they were worth and by their continuous pressing, they managed to add 3 more goals to their total and so won by 4-3 when the game concluded. There was a heavy wind blowing throughout the match. Mr. Trotter was referee.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Earl and Countess of Carnarvon are making a short stay in Cairo previous to going to Colombo. Lord Carnarvon was perhaps the most adventurous traveller in the ranks of the peerage before his marriage to Miss Almina Wombwell, ten years ago, but he nows finds plenty to occupy in the care of his exten sive estates He owns some 35000 acres of land, including HIghclere Castle, Newbury, Bretby Park, Burton-on-Trent, and Pixton Park, Dulverton. At Highclare Castle he has the finest collection in Er gland of pictures by Gainsborough and Reynolds and among other interesting historic relics in that stately Hamp­shire home is the table on which Napoleon I signed his abdication.

Bishop Potter, who is at present on a visit to Cairo, has written to the "New York Times" offering £150 for the restoration of a stone escutcheon which, he understands, has keen removed by some American relic hunter from over the entrance door of the farm house in Northamptonshire which was the home of Washington's ancestors. The Bishop argues that the escutcheon should be replaced in its former position an international monument.
Lord de Clifford and party left Cairo yester­day for a trip up the river on a dahabieh. They will return to the Savoy in about three weeks.
Sir William Garstin left for Assouan last night on a tour of inspection.

div.head: JUDGE AND MRS. MARSHALL ARE BANK AT CAIRO
div.p: Chitty Bey has arrived at Cairo.

Sir Charles Scotter entertained a party to dinner at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening, the guests being: Mr. and Mrs. George Royle, Mr. MItchell Junes, Major and Mrs Wynne, and Mr. Harrison. The Bishop of New York had a party of 5. Mr. and Mrs. Jay Gould entertained two guests, and Mr, Gatman had also two guests.
Yesterday's arrivals at the Savoy Hotel Include : Mr. and Mrs. D. S. Ellsworth, of New York, who have spent many winters at the Savoy before, also Baron Bassus, who is well known in Cairo.

Other arrivals at the Savoy were Mr. Max Schoenfeld, from New York ; Mr. and Mrs. G. Louis Boissevain New York; Miss Edwards, New York; Mr. Paul Niedick, Wiesbaden ; Mr. and Mrs. J. F. . Mr. C. J. Cornish, the well known writer on open-air topics, was attacked by a very severe illness some months ago- He recovered sufficiently for the prospect of a visit to Egypt to be entertained on his behalf, but a grave relapse caused that project to be postponed. From that relapse he has in some measure recovered, bat bis condition is still a cause for grave anxiety
We have pleasure in announcing the nomi­nation of Mr. George Discono to the post of British Consular Agent for the province of Sharkieh.

div.head:
THE ELECTIONS.
INDEPENDENT LABOUR PARTY.
MR. BALFOUR WITHOUT A SEAT.

div.p: The members of the Independent Labour Party are pledging themselves to form a distinct group and to abstain strictly from identifying themselves with any section, whether of Liberals or Conservatives.
As it is now unlikely that Mr. Balfour will secure a seat before the assembly of parliam ment it is expected that Mr. Akers Douglas will head the Opposition.
liberals 374, Labour 34, Unionists-115, Nationalists79. Five Liberal gains are reported to-day

div.head:
THE JAPANESE BUDGET
A BIG DEFICIT.

div.p: The budget .for the coming year shows a net deficit of 790,000,000 yen, though the revenue on account of ordinary expenditure shows a surplus of 10.000,000. The deficit will be covered by a loan, war taxes, arid the Russian payment on account of prisoners.

The magazine of the Brasilian ironolad Aquidahan exploded near here at midnight. The vessel sank in three minutes. The commander and four rear admirals who were accompanying the Minister of Marine on s tour of inspection perished. It it reported that altogether three hundred men were drowned. *
believed that the number of killed amounts to 300
The Conference has decided to alter fire clauses of the regulations concerning the intro­duction of firearms into Morocco.
Austria and Servia have severed commercial relations.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Captain J. S Liddell, Royal Engineers,Cairo, has been promoted major his advancement to field rank comes after over eighteen years' service. Major Liddell got his first commision in July, 1887, his captaincy in April, 1898and he has spent a good deal of his service in Egypt, the last year or so in connection with the telegraph Department. He served is Kitohener's advance up the Nile, 1899, arid the operations against the Khalifa (medal with clasp 4th class Medjidieh). The next senior captain of the Sappers, Captain G O. Bigge, is also serving at Cairo.
Brevet Major W. J. Venonr, D.8.O., Royal Dublin Fusiliers, serving with the Depot, Naas, has been selected for the adjutancy of the 3rd. Battalion (Kildare Militia), Naas.
Lieutenant Halfpenny, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, on absoption, has been posted to the 1st Battalion at Belfast He was recently with the West African Frontier Force.
The following "small talk" re the Innis killings will be read with interest by the 2nd Battalion at Cairo:

The following non-commissioned officers an men have been awarded third-class certificate of education Lance Corpora's J Berming ham R. Lynn, J. W. Wright, and R Hastings privates M'Mahaffey, J. Hall, C. Sweeney, A Beggs, S. Patterson, W. Archibald, J. Young J. Connors, J. H. Wilson, W. Calderb& inc. T rinney, J. M. Crackeu, and W. Danbar ; Boy H. Fitcgerald, G. Boll, and W. Murdock.

Sergeant J. Rooks qualified at an examina ,ion held at the School of Masketry, Hythe on the 12th of December, 1905; order of merit 15. Colour-Sergeant, W. T Prior has bee posted to the regimental depot, in relief of Colour-Sergeaht H. Woodward, who has bee posted to the 1st Battalion for duty. Corporal L. H. F. Burnett and Lance Corporal G. comp ton proceeded to the curragh on the 1st inst For a course of gymnastics. Bandsman T Oakley and Private F. Bowey have been disiharged to pension, after completing twenty one years' service. A draft of twenty five re cruits arrived from the regimental depot o he 6th inst Privates J. J. Halpin; W. fuller Ion, J. M'Cullough, and M. Carey have bee appointer lance corporals. Corporal J. H. How arrived from the regimental depot on the 6th inst. Sergeant Master Tailor F, Nolan has re engaged for the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers For such a term as shall complete twenty one gears' service. The cooking prize for the month hasbeen awarded to C. Company. A party of six men, under Corporal W. Griffon, precceded to Carrick fergus on the 8th inst. for duty wit the Army Ordnance Corps.

The Army Council has at present under consideration a proposal respecting the appoint­ment of certain qualified officers of the Auxiliary Forces as acting adjutants of corps of Militia and Volunteer Artillery, in consequence of the difficulty experienced in obtaining the services of officers of the Royal Garrison Artillery.

Me. Arnold Forster's project of shifting the Royal Engineers from Chatham to Salisbury Plain in order to hand over Chatham quarters to the Admiralty, has been knocked on the head, and properly so. This wild-cat scheme would have involved an enormous outlay, with no commensurate benefit to the army.

Sir John Fisher has found it necessary to issue a circular contradicting the oft repeated assertion that radical changes in the garb of the handymen were in contemplation. It appears that the changes are to be made in the kit, and they will have the effect of redu­cing the ocst of that outfit

div.head: HIGHER PRICES FOR AMERICAN COTTON
div.p: The New Orleans cotton, at the final sitting last week, passed a resolution adopting the committee's report flouring the selling of the balance of the cotton crop at a minimum price of 15 cents a pound. TheConvention also decided to recommend a 10 percent reduction in the acreage by diversification of next years crops. This recommendation was forced upon the Convention by the opposi­tion, who feared that over planting would be the result of the 15 cent basis.

President Jordan, of the Southern Cotton Association, declared that this was the first time in the history of the Sooth that the planters dominated the situation. He be­lieved that the "bears" and spinners were now at the mercy of the growers, and that the Northern exchanges had lost the power of making a price which might bankrupt the planters. He stated that if the remainder of the crop is sold at 15 cento it would not more than even up matters, as the New York hears had beaten the price down formerly to below
10 cents a pound.

"The mills," said he, "will not suffer, as they demand cotton, and millions of new spindles have been erected since last year By judicious planting and careful holding the speculators might he out mar ceuvred. and the men who produce the staple reap the proper reward for their labours.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

div.head: THE STORY OF THE KHEDIVE'S SHARES
div.p: Mr. Frederick Greenwood writes to the "Times" : -

Sir,—In "The Times" of Friday week a short letter from Mr. Oppenheim broke down Mr. Lucien Wolf's account of a con­versation which, he said, took place between the first-named gentleman and myself in November. Mr. Wolf's report of this con­versation appeared in a history of the purchase of the Khedive's Suez. Canal shares. It was a very positive statement Set forth with the particularity which is so alluring to belief, it had the farther advantage of surprise for your readers were told that they, were misled if they ever credited my account of the fortunate Egyptian coup. .He (Mr. Wolf) had a different story to tell; the tenth being— But his meaning had better be stated as understood by others. Quite correctly, the "Saturday Review" expressed it as follows Mr. Wolfs historiette "gives credit for the idea that led to the transaction, not to Mr. Greenwood,.but to Mr. Oppenheim. according to Mr. Wolf Mr, Greenwood did nothing
more than make practicable a suggestion thrown out by Mr. Oppenheim at a dinner- table.''

Therefore, in a letter which you were good enough to print, I pointed out to Mr. Wolf that, unless he was mistaken, I must have been gnilty of pretensions meanly conceived and untruthfully asserted. Or, if not, guilty, but yet unable aftter 80 years to meet his imputations with absolute disproof, I must lie under lasting suspicion, as the least hurtful consequence of Mr. wolfd error By good fortune, however, such means of disproof were not lacking ; and, warning Mr. Wolf of this circumstance, I was obliged to add that the conversation he reported so precisely never took place. I

But he would not believe me, which was a pity. For, while he was writing to yon a per sistent letter urging that he had a source of information preferable to unneandoontra<|iotory of it, correction of himself was On the way to Printing-house sqnarefrom this identical source Reading Mr. Wolf a story as other people did, Mr. Oppenheim wrote at once to reject it, and his denial is decisive. only two persons now or at any time could speak to the truth of the matter, and both repudiate Mr. Wolt's inferential conversation, with the misrepresen tation of facts which it conveys.
It was not unlikely, I thought, that he would acknowledge so grave a mistake when its character was shown to him He has not done so, however, and I pass to, other matters—the least important first

There Was a warning in my previous letter that, in reading Mr. Wotfs history, care should betaken against confusing the Canal, the property of a French company, with the Khedive's boxes of Canal shares, which were a different property with a different ownership The indebtedness of the French company, the Various expedients of its president to raise money on the Canal itself, were not to be con­founded with the Khedive's difficulties at an­other time and the bargaining then for his infructuous shares. Such a walking may have seemed unnecessary, but it was not so. Quite recently it was said in, a journal of the highest rank that, when Sir Andrew Clarke recom­mended , his Government to buy the Suez Canal, "he anticipated by five years the idea of Lord Beaconsfield and Mr. Greenwood."

history seems to have put the same into many heads ; and his relation of M de' Lerseps's financial troubles and ex pedients was certainly indentions. He speaks of "the first chance of buying out the company'' —a chance which if it means purchase of the French Canal by the Britannic Government, its transfer to the British Crown as State property (and so this "first chanoe" has been understood) was never offered and never possible. that it -was never offered appears from Mr. Wolfs narrative, when it is not read at a glance ; while it Was made impossible for anything but madness by an interlocked combination of political and financial obstruction formidable in both countries. There was a scheme for selling the Canal to "the maritime Towers," but that was not selling to the British Govern ment There was a proposal for making it the property of an English company, of which the same thing most be said, though the descrip- tion of it here is "sale to Great Britain." Other proposals were made, and, when they are all reconnected, all are seen to have failed because from the nature of men and things they could not succeed. Yet there is a common impression among Mr. .Wolfs readers at a glance (he is lucky if they are Dot three out of four) that Lord Granville might have bought the suezCanalfor his Government in 1871 ;that it very weak of Him to reject the chance ; and that the Khedive's shares came into the transaction. A more accurate and edifying suggestion would have been to contrast the property in the Canal which we obtained ,in peace and have held in quietness, with the French property—if we could have bought it from the weakness and poverty of the France of that day. What would have been its price, as compared with- the fonr millions paid to Ismail is What would it have been as a commodity, and what its political value—its shares distributed among a multitude cf French proprietors — compared with the individual mass brought fronr the Khedive's Treasury to be all British and all in the hands of the Government buying the Sure Canal A far better thing was done in 1875.
But, according to Mr. wolf, the worse and the impossible thing was attempted by Mr. ' Disraeli, in the spring of 1874. For reasons of great weight in themselves, he commissioned
the late Baron Rothschild "to intimate con­

fidentially to M do bessops that the British Government were prepared to purchase the Suez Canal outright if suitable terms could be arranged ;'' and the present Lord rothsechild went to Paris at", once to submit this proposal to the president of the Canal Company. To purchase the Canal outright. If so (Mr. Wolf gives no authority for this statement), we have here the strongest evidence of Disraeli's an* xiety to obtain a proprietary hold on the Canal, but not of the sagacity which avoids all roads to foredoomed failure. cassio might as well have sounded the moon upon the probabilities of a deal in Desdemoha. It seem" that Mr Disraeli made this attempt in May, 1874. But in April—only a month before (I follow Mt Wolfs narrative)—his Government had ascet taiued through a conversation between Lord Derby and the French Ambassador that the French Government would not listen to acquisition by ' the maritime Powers," let alone transference to England outright Unlike Mr. Disraeli's proposal, Lord Derby's would have allowed France to remain in the proprietary, 1st any rate ; but it was rejected with indiges tion. Naturally. The continued ownership ef the Canal as theretofore held remained a na­tional affair. A point of honour with the Government, it was at the same time a rearoused demand of "Chauvinism," consequent upon an on appeased Anglo Frenoh quarrel over the Canal tolls. In these conditions it was that Mr. Disraeli's envoy, approaobed the Othello of the piece. And, "as soon as his proposals were unfolded to M. de Lesseps, that gentle­man declared emphatically that the sale of the Canal to any company, Power, or group of Powers was totally out of the question."

A strange story The proved impossibilities of 1871 were yet more impossible in 1874, and Mr. Disraeli did not know it! They had been added to remarkably in the interval by open evideuoe of a Franco Russian arrangement for "combined action io defence French interests in the Suez Canal": yet Mr. Disraeli went on to receive the inevitable rebuff. 'Twas unlike him. Yet I do not suggest that Mr. Wolf makes this statement without authority that quite satisfies himself But, being concerned for a just understanding of the matter, I am obliged to add that I have among my papers a memoran dum, written in 1896, whih sets out a very d fforent aooount of Lord Rohschilds visit to Paris in 1874 and the object of it, and that I believe the authority for this different account as good as any that Mr. Wolf oan show.

Mr. Wolf now goes on to say that, undis- oouraged by his failure to boy the Canal outright., Mr." Disraeli "continued his confe rences with Baron Rothschild io Piccadilly, seeking with him some other means" of modify­ing a dangerous monopoly. Thera was still the expedient of a largo purchase of share on the various Bourses, but still the difficulty also that before a sufficient number could be bought in open market the price would become prohi bitive and the object of the purchase would probably be detected No way out of that difficulty could be found unless great blocks of shares could be bought quietly here and there. "In this way"—and now we come to a very interesting. point—"the idea of approaching the Khedive first arose . . It was accord-
ingly resolved that overtures should be made to him, and Baron Rothschild undertook on the part of his firm to conduct the delicate negotia­tion."

Now that statement, as will presently be seen, stands very much in need of positive and precise authority. The days were moving on from May, 1874, when Mr. Disraeli's proposal to the French was rejected, to and through the more promising year 1875; for meanwhile the Khedive's debts were heaping up at a tremendous rate, and the time was near when he could have no other or no efficient asset than those unproductive shares. But though all through that increasingly porten­tous interval Baron Rothsehild—but no, not all through, but nearly. Although daring many months in 1874-5 Baron Rothschild repeated his overtures to the Khedive,he did so in vain. it seemed as though the lost opportunities of 1870 71 were final''—they were never to come again.

' This was in the late summer of 1875''- the late sommer; three months before the second week of November, or perhaps less. At this point "Mr. Disraeli had probably given op all hope ." which, however, could hardly have been, and certainly would not have mattered, unless Baron Rothschild had resigned all hope too ; and his name never appears again in Mr. Wolf s narrative tilt it is brought ion connexion with providing the money for a completed bargain. But on this reprerentation of the case—which is not mir e. not willing'y repeated by me nor bdievingly—at what a point to give up Read Mr. Wolfs description of the Khedive's plight from the first week of October, 1875 "The Times," December 26 of last year), or M. Lesage's more c mprehenrive story in the Revue de Paris" for November 15 It is a story of financial panic, and for the Khedive cf headlong descent into bankruptcy, unless he conld raise an unhoped-for snm of money by December 1 (1875). A few weeks before that fatal day. however, certain French syndicates offered secretly to supply the money, either by purchase of the Khedive's shares or by advance, then noon snob farms as would cover an actual sale transaction. The shares would become French property in three months by an automatic process useful for stiffing English susceptibilities when the shares ware openly appropriated. (This significant detail is sup plied by M. Lesage.)

Behold, then, the situation in the first week in November. But where is Mr. Disraeli's place in the picture, and where Baron Roth­schild's Opportunity the moat perfect for their purpose has arrived, after visibly rushing on for a month at the least Have they taken hold cf it Have they made an attempt to do so ? Do they know anything about it An affirmative answer has never yet been given.

If the well-in firmed English financier did repeat his endeavour to buy when be saw that the Khedive's affairs must go to ruin in a few weeks without some such relief as soiling (and being on the look-out so long, with a great purpose in hand, Rothschild could not be unaware of that dilemma), or if he again approached the Khedive later, when the Frenchmen round their way to his Highness, some record of that last aud moat urgent attempt should appear in a history like .Mr. Wolfs. But no such record stands there or anywhere else. Or suppose that Baron Roth­sohild found that he could not prevail against the French negotiators on this supreme occa­sion, would he not warn his Government that the French were at work and likely to succeed I To do so was In the duty which, according to Mr. Wolf, this most scrupulous man of business and good Englishman had undertaken. And did he give any such warning = Mr. Wolf does not say he did, and there is proof that he did not

Yet another series of difficulties comes into view when we consider the Khedive's part in the matter as here presented. Are we to believe that Ismail, who had keen pressed by an English Rothschild to sell his shares,and had heard the same persuasion "over and over again" down to the late summer of 1875, forgot all about it in the desperate need of November "He did not wish to sell." But Ismail was no dullard. A man of extremely quick and penetrating mind, he could see as plainly as the draftsman of the French proposals that he was to sign a loan arrangement tint was purchase in effect, attended by long lasting and extortion­ate claims for interest such as Baron R .th- schild would never dream of contending for. Yet, with the Rothschild offer still open, still urged upon him as we are to under­stand, he never turned from the French syn­dicates to see what he could make of it Even as a means of putting up his price he gave it no attention. .Incredible But what if, giving up all hope just when an unsur­passable opportunity presented itself, Baron Rothschild had turned his back on the whole business and would do no more in it That might explain the Khedive's conduct of the affair; but what is to explain the supposed conduct of Mr. Disraeli's friend and agent in a matter of inch immense importance We are here in presence of the most extravagant suggestion of all. As for Ismail's refusal to sell, we know that he did sell to the English as soon as another agent of Mr. Disraeli's offered to buy. And yet the head of the house of Rothsohild could not have been thought an in- sufficiently responsible negotiator.

What, then, is to be made of all this 7 Its immediate suggestion is that Baron Rothschild coaid not have been engaged in buying the Khedive's shares. I have my own opinion and my reasons for it, but at the moment only say that no friend of the Rothschilds can believe that he was, upon Mr. Wolf's account of the matter. better that he should never have taken it up than that he shoud drop it at the critical time ; critical, but, as the event proved, not hopelss, though the Government was left in the dark and without help till the last hour of a great and final opportunity was running out. When was his olient, Mr. Disraeli.apprised of the opportunity Not till this last hour, and not then by Baron Rothschild. Yet both of them had been eagerly looking for it for many months, and it had been glaring at them for almost as many weeks! The tale is all wrong somewhere. I can not and do not say that Mr. Wolf is still without authority for his suggestive assertions, his assertive suggestions, on this which is a special part of his subject. Bat they greatly need good authority ; he offers none, and the considerations above recited forbid belief that he can adduce corroboration of the necessary kind. It is more probable that his account of the Rothschild endeavour to buy the Khedive's shares is inferential, as was his figmentary and injurious report of a dinner-table conversation. Mark that, at the best this endeavour, if ever made, was abortive. It failed in the hands of Mr. Disraeli and Baron Rothschild When the Khedive's shares were actually passing into the possession of the French, neither of them was aware of the transaction. And whit would "the dangerous monopoly" have been if that "transaction" had been completed
Here I come to a stop, hoping it Will be believed that I write this most unwillingly, and sure that it will be understood that I am placed under compulsion to do so.

div.head: THE LATE REV. HASKETT SMITH
div.p: The Rev. haskett smith, M.A., F.R.G.S., the weil known Egyptologist, whose death on the 12th inst our London Correspondent announced by telegram,had travelled exten­sively in egypt and the east He visited Cairo and Damascus 14 times each, and made fours journeys up the Nile. He had lectured upon Egypt in all parts of the world. For tome years he resided upon Mount Cannel

A correspondent, writing in the "Westmin­ster Gazette" with reference to the deceased, rays The Rev. Haskett Smith was beloved by many, and I am sure that the news of his untimely end will bring sadness to the thou sands of artisans and others whom he had addressed during the last few years. I think I may say he was the most successful lecturer of the day, if:the number of engagements be a criterion. Last season the amount of his travelling approximated, to 16,000 miles ; he was delivering a lecture practically every day, and occasionally he gave two on one day. The Welsh miners seemed to appreciate his work to the full. Prom down in the Rhondda Valley demands for His services were always coming to hand. It was often difficult to find dates for the number of places anxious to have him. The secret of his success was his graphic description manner, his enthusiastic devotion to his subject, and the overflow­ing bonhomie of the man. There are those who can speak with intimate knowledge of his goodness of heart, of bis kindly interest is his younger brethren, and bis abso- inte lack of anything like envy. He never took exception to criticism himself, and I do not remember hearing him say an advene word regarding any man in his own profession—I
mean the profession of lecturing.

Mr. Haskett Smith was a Wrangler and a Scholar of Christ's College, Cambridge. Ha travelled much in Oriental lands and edited Murray's "Handbook to Syria and Palestine." It would take up too much space to speak of his many journeys, but it may he interesting to relate that he first visited Palestine at Invitation of his intimate friend laurence Oliphant, and that he lived on Mount Carmel tor several years. Mr. Haskett Smith also made three lecturing tours through Australia, four tours through New Zealand, and he spent nearly two years in the United States. He was an exceedingly good conversationalist, and from the huge fund of knowledge of men and things which he had amassed on bis travels ha was able to produce witty stories, appro­priate anecdotes, and apt experiences to illustrate his remarks. He was a man of jovial appearance, and I think he did enjoy his life and loved to assist others to enjoy theirs. His engagement book was completely full te the end of March, hut the thousands of people who were awaiting his kindly presence and racy speech are doomed to disappointment The voice that has charmed andin formed so many is stilled for ever.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound

div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
